(b) XRD pattern of Co@C, Co8Ni2@C, Co2Ni8@C, and Ni@C. (c) Ni 2p XPS spectra of Ni@C, Co2Ni8@C, and Co8Ni2@C. (d) Co 2p XPS spectra of Co@C, Co8Ni2@C, and Co2Ni8@C. Fig. 3 (a) Normalized Ni K-edge XANES spectra of Co8Ni2@C, Co2Ni8@C, Ni@C, Ni foil and NiO. (b) Normalized Co K-edge XANES spectra of Co8Ni2@C, Co2Ni8@C, Co@C, Co foil and CoO. Fourier transformed (FT) k2-weighted χ (k)-function of the EXAFS spectra for Ni K-edge (c) and Co K-edge (d). Typical EXAFS fitting curves of Ni (e) and Co (f) for various samples at K space. (g) The wavelet transforms spectrums of Ni and Co atoms in various samples. Fig. 4 (a-d) HRTEM mages of catalysts Ni@C, Co2Ni8@C, Co8Ni2@C, and Co@C. Fig. 7 (a) Plot of initial rate of reaction as a function of catalyst loading in liquid phase; (b) The catalytic properties of Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C at different reaction temperatures, Reaction conditions: methanol (35 mL), p-CNB (1 g), catalyst (20 mg), 1 MPa H2, 1200 rpm; (c) p-CNB concentration was used as the curve of ln r0 against ln CA for Ni@C and Co2Ni8@C at different initial p-CNB concentrations. Fig. 10 (a) Differential charge density redistributions of the C72Ni54Co10 (up) and C72Ni64 (down) systems. (b) Electron localization functions (ELFs) of the C72Ni54Co10 (up) and C72Ni64 (down) systems from DFT calculations. Graphical abstract Encapsulated catalysts have become a new strategy for catalysis in harsh reaction environments due to their unique structural and functional reorganization properties, and they have been widely applied in fields such as electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and thermocatalysis. In strategies involving encapsulated catalysts, the optimization of electronic properties on the carbon layer surface to enhance reactivity while maintaining adequate encapsulation poses a challenge due to the trade-off between stability, poison resistance, and acid resistance against the performance of metal nanoparticles. Herein, an alloying strategy for Co-Ni bimetal was proposed, which achieves a delicate balance between catalyst activity and stability. Ni plays a pivotal role in promoting the formation of graphitized carbon and the construction of an effective encapsulation structure, thereby ensuring the stability of the catalyst. Co incorporation and alloying with Ni modulates the electronic state and D-band structure within the metallic core, effectively breaking the electronic cloud segregation barrier imposed by the carbon shell. This modulation notably enhances the efficiency of reactions. For the hydrogenation of p-CNB to p-CAN, Co2Ni8@C exhibits an extremely low apparent activation energy (53.40 KJ/mol), as well as > 99 % conversion and selectivity. Keywords Alloying effect Non-noble metal Encapsulated catalyst Hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The process of synthesizing amines from nitroaromatic compounds was first reported in 1842, constituting a classic reduction reaction[1]. However, it continues to attract significant interest from researchers. On the one hand, both substrates and products serve as highly crucial intermediates in academic organic synthesis and industrial chemical production[2–4]. On the other hand, the catalytic hydrogenation strategy, incorporating the concepts of green chemistry and atom economy, has brought new vitality to this classic reaction and has gradually replaced the traditional stoichiometric reduction method[5–8]. The noble metals catalysts (such as Pd, Pt, Ru, etc.) are widely employed to impel this catalytic process due to their excellent hydrogenation activity[9,10]. However, when confronted with challenging substrates like halogen-substituted nitroaromatics, hydrogenation-induced dehalogenation frequently occurs, resulting in an undesirable outcome[11]. They are very versatile and critical compounds. As the presence of the C-X (X = F, Cl, Br, I) portion facilitates the compound's entry into subsequent functionalization via cross-coupling or other relevant chemical transformations. To enhance the selectivity of the target product, halogenated aniline, it is common to use methods such as adding inhibitors, shielding, and poisoning noble metals. Unfortunately, these lead to a series of additional issues, including decreased product quality, low utilization of noble metals, and increased costs[10,12]. Non-noble metals, abundant in the Earth's crust, economically viable, and highly biocompatible, have emerged as promising alternatives to noble metals[1,5,13]. In 2005, R. Raja utilized metallic Co-based catalysts in this field[14]. In 2013, Beller reported on the use of nanostructured Fe2O3-based catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of nitroaromatics to produce aniline[15]. Furthermore, Raney-Ni catalysts have even found practical applications in industry to a certain extent. However, non-noble metal catalysts face significant challenges due to their low catalytic activity and instability in harsh environments. For instance, the generation of H-X in the previously mentioned hydrogenation dehalogenation side reactions can cause the leaching of active metal components in the catalyst. The development of novel strategies for catalyst design never ceases. Bao et al. introduced the concept of chainmail catalysts, where the stable carbon layer can shield the inner metal core from the deleterious effects of the reaction environment[16]. However, the improvement of structural stability, toxicity resistance, and acid resistance of these catalysts often comes at the cost of sacrificing the catalytic performance of metal nanoparticles. The encapsulation of the carbon layer offers a distinctive shielding effect for the metal's d orbitals[17]. This not only prevents strong chemical bonding between the metal and toxic substances but also attenuates its adsorption with reactants. Therefore, researchers often modify the carbon layer to disturb the local π bonding system of the carbon network, thereby enhancing the adsorption of reactants. For instance, this involves introducing heteroatoms, strengthening functional groups, and so forth, on the carbon layer[18–22]. However, a more effective approach to enhance its catalytic performance could be to directly influence the electron transfer from the metal core to the carbon layer by altering the d-band structure of the metal core. Alloying two different metals can alter the electronic states of the metals. When there is an overlap between the valence bands of the constituent metals, the resulting d-band of the alloyed metal will vary depending on the degree of overlap. According to the Hume-Rothery Rules, forming an alloy with Co and Ni is a feasible method, which also leads to the adjustment of the metal's d-band structure[23]. Hence, alloying Co with Ni has the potential to break the maximum electron transport limit of a single metal (Co or Ni) to the outer carbon layer, ensuring the catalytic activity of the encapsulated catalyst while significantly enhancing its stability. Here, we employed a simple method of direct thermolysis of organometallic coordination polymers (OCPs) to design and obtain a catalyst with a graphite carbon layer encapsulating a metallic Co-Ni alloy core. The Co2Ni8@C catalyst achieved a dual pursuit of catalytic activity and stability. Furthermore, we achieved the regulation of the metal alloy ratio within the catalyst. By varying the alloy ratio, we discovered that the encapsulated structure can only be obtained in catalysts with a high Ni content, benefiting from the superior catalytic graphitization function of Ni. Moreover, the DFT simulation results indicated that the Co-Ni alloy metal core could transfer more electrons to the graphite carbon layer. This led to the catalyst surface possessing an optimized electron distribution, as well as a more efficient and favorable hydrogenation pathway for the conversion of p-chloronitrobenzene (p-CNB) to p-chloroaniline (p-CAN). 2 Experimental section Details of materials, materials characterization, and DFT simulation methods are provided in the supporting information. 2.1 Synthesis of samples For the Co@C-OCPs, 75 mL of absolute ethanol and 75 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were respectively added into a 250 mL beaker using a measuring cylinder. Then, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (6 mmol) and the organic ligand isonicotinic acid (4.47 mmol) were added. The mixture was magnetically stirred for 1 h at 60 °C to ensure complete dissolution. Subsequently, 4 mL of ammonia water, serving as a deprotonation reagent, was added to solution. The mixture was further magnetically stirred for 6 h at 60 °C in a water bath and then allowed to stand overnight at room temperature. The precipitate was obtained by filtering the mixture in the beaker through a vacuum filtration device and washed several times with DMF. The samples were then placed in an air blower oven and dried at 85 °C for 10 h. After drying, the required samples were ready. For the Co8Ni2@C-OCPs, following the same preparation method as above, only the metal sources were altered to Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1.2 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (4.8 mmol). For the Co2Ni8@C-OCPs, the metal sources were Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (4.8 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1.2 mmol), and the others are the same as above. For the Ni@C-OCPs, the metal source was Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (6 mmol), and the others are the same as above. For the catalyst preparation, the corresponding precursor OCPs sample was first ground into powder. It was then heated to 600 °C in a tubular furnace under an N2 atmosphere at a rate of 1 °C/min and maintained at that temperature for 30 min. Afterward, the furnace was allowed to cool to room temperature, and the resulting black powder was retrieved, which constituted the catalyst samples Ni@C, Co2Ni8@C, Co8Ni2@C, and Co@C. For the Co2Ni8@C-shell and Ni@C-shell, the procedure involved mixing 1.5 g of NH4Cl with 50.0 mg of catalysts, grinding the mixture evenly. The mixed powder was then heated at 350 °C for 16 h. Following this, the resulting powder was washed in a 1 M HCl solution for 3 h to eliminate the metal, and then dried at 85 °C for 12 h. 2.2 Catalytic hydrogenation tests The hydrogenation performance of the catalyst was investigated through hydrogen reduction of nitrobenzene derivatives into the corresponding aniline, serving as a probe reaction. The reaction was conducted in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave, sourced from Shanghai Yanzheng Experimental Instrument Co., Ltd. The reaction was detected using a gas chromatogram−mass spectrometer (Agilent 5973 N) and gas chromatography (Agilent 7890 A, FID detector), both equipped with an HP-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.20 mm × 0.25 µm). The reaction was analyzed employing the area normalization method. In addition, the yield was also verified using the p-CAN external standard method (Fig. S1). 2.3 Materials characterization The structure and morphology of the samples were analyzed SEM (FEI QUANTA FEG 650) and TEM (Tecnai G2 F30/F20). The average particle size ds of metal core in the Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C can be determined using the equation: ds = ∑nidi 3/∑nidi 2. Here, the particle sizes (di) are directly measured from the micrograph using the DigitalMicrograph software, and the particle number (ni) measured separately was approximately 60. Raman spectra were obtained with a Horrible Evolution Raman spectrometer using 532 nm laser irradiation. XRD patterns were collected on a ThermoFisher ARL SCINTAG XTRA diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA, using a step size of 0.04° and a scanning rate of 2°/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a ThermoFisher Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with an Al Kα source. FFT-IR spectroscopy was conducted using KBr pellets on a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer. The metal content (Co and Ni) in the samples and their pickling solutions was analyzed with a Beijing Purkinje TAS-990 atomic absorption spectrophotometer using the air-acetylene flame method. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a STA499C analyzer from 303 K to 973 K at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min under N2. Samples were purged at 383 K for 2 h in N2 before heating from 303 K to 973 K. Mass signals were monitored on a quadrupole mass spectrometer at m/z = 15, 17, 27, 28, 44, and 45. In the H2-TPR test, approximately 50 mg of the sample was purged with dry Ar (50 mL/min, purity > 99.999 vt%) at 100 °C for 1 h. The furnace temperature was then lowered to 50 °C, and a 10.0 vt% H2/Ar flow (35 mL/min) was introduced. MS analysis was performed from 50 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, monitoring the mass signal at m/z = 2 amu. The H2-TPD of the catalyst was analyzed using a Microtrac BELCat II Chemisorption Analyzer. A sample (80–100 mg) was dried and pre-treated by ramping the temperature from room temperature to 120 °C at 10 °C/min under He (50 mL/min) for 1 h. After cooling to 50 °C, the sample was saturated with a 10 % H2/Ar mixture (50 mL/min) for 1 h, followed by Ar (50 mL/min) for 1 h to remove weakly adsorbed H2. The temperature was then increased to 800 °C at 10 °C/min under Ar for desorption, with evolved gases detected using a Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD). EXAFS measurements were conducted at Beamline 07A1 of the Taiwan Light Source (TLS) at the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center (NSRRC). The beamline features a fixed-exit double crystal Si (111) monochromator covering an X-ray energy range of 5 to 23 keV. The end-station is equipped with three ionization chambers and a Lytle detector for both transmission and fluorescence X-ray absorption spectroscopy. The X-ray beam size on the sample is approximately 0.5 x 0.25 mm (H x V), with a photon flux exceeding 1 x 101⁰ photons per second. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterizations of OCPs Thanks to the non-specific coordination of metal cations with carboxylic acid ligands, OCPs with tunable Co/Ni rations were prepared by dropwise addition of ammonia to a mixture of the organic ligand isonicotinic acid, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O [24,25]. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the FT-IR spectra of a range of OCPs are compared with that of free isonicotinic acid. In the spectrum of isonicotinic acid, the most characteristic band is observed at 1705 cm−1, which corresponds to the CO = stretching vibrations (νC=Ocarboxyl group)[26]. However, in the spectrum of OCPs, the band at 1705 cm−1 disappears, and two strong adsorption bands emerge at 1597 and 1389 cm−1, corresponding to symmetric and asymmetric vibrations of COO– groups[27]. These results collectively indicate the complete deprotonation of isonicotinic acid during complex formation[28]. Additionally, it chelates with varying ratios of Co2+ and Ni2+. The XRD patterns of OCPs, as shown in Fig. 1b, reveal numerous sharp peaks within the 10-35° range for OCPs at four different Co/Ni ratios, including Co@C-OCPs, Co8Ni2@C-OCPs, Co2Ni8@C-OCPs, and Ni@C-OCPs. Indicating the successful coordination of ligands and metal ions, the resulting OCPs have a crystal structure, which mutually confirms with the above conclusion. Furthermore, certain characteristic diffraction peaks at approximately 15, 23, and 39° in these XRD patterns closely resemble those observed in MOFs synthesized using Co and Ni as metal ions, along with isonicotinic acid as organic ligands[29–31]. As identified by the SEM images (Fig. 1e-f), all the OCPs successfully form a 3D hierarchical structure. Furthermore, the structural shape of OCPs exhibits a regular variation with changes in Co/Ni ratio. With increasing Co content, the long, plate-like structures originally attributed to Ni@C-OCPs slowly disappear. They appear as long stick structures in Co2Ni8@C-OCPs. However, in the higher Co contents of Co8Ni2@C-OCPs and Co@C-OCPs, small granular structures appear. 3.2 Synthesis and characterizations of CoNi@C The resulting four OCPs samples were pyrolyzed to obtain the corresponding catalyst samples Co@C, Co8Ni2@C, Co2Ni8@C, and Ni@C. And, the pyrolysis process was analyzed by thermogravimetric (TG) (Fig. S2) and Mass spectrum (MS) (Fig. S3). Statistical analysis of the thermogravimetric results of all OCPs samples (Fig. 2 a) revealed that they experienced four stages of weightlessness. However, each weight loss interval of OCPs exhibits a unique distribution in temperature, which is likely related to their Co/Ni ratio[32]. For all OCPs, the first mass loss zone exhibits an endothermic thermal behavior and is accompanied by strong H2O and CH4 signals in the mass spectra. This process involves the endothermic evaporation of both free and bound water molecules from the surface of OCPs at the onset of pyrolysis, followed by the gradual collapse of the organic skeleton. The second and third mass loss intervals are characterized by extensive exothermic behavior and more intense CO, CO2, C2H4, and CH4 signals in the mass spectrum. This corresponds to the extensive collapse of the organic skeleton. The temperature range of 380 to 430 °C (third mass loss interval), accompanied by an exothermic signal along with a small quantity of reducing gases (CO, C2H4), and the reduction product H2O, likely arises from redox reactions during pyrolysis. These reactions lead to the reduction of metals and the formation of unique carbon materials, crucial for the encapsulation of metal structures within carbon layers[33].The final weight loss interval, associated with endothermic signals, likely corresponds to the decomposition of unstable carbon species within the carbon matrix formed during pyrolysis. In summary, the weight loss processes of all samples occur below 600 °C. Therefore, for better comparison among the catalyst samples, pyrolysis is conducted at 600 °C for all OCPs samples. Further, the phase composition of the catalyst samples can be derived from the XRD pattern (Fig. 2b), where the inset depicts their diffraction peaks corresponding to the (111) planes. Ni@C contains face-centered cubic (fcc) metallic Ni (PDF#65–0380), while Co@C includes the fcc metallic Co (PDF#15–0806)[34]. The remaining samples, Co2Ni8@C and Co8Ni2@C, exhibit diffraction patterns similar to those of Ni@C and Co@C, respectively. It is worth noting that the Co/Ni molar ratios vary from 2: 8 to 8: 2, and the (111) peaks of Co2Ni8@C and Co8Ni2@C progressively shifting from a higher angle (approaching the Bragg position of fcc Ni at 44.4°) to a lower angle (approaching the Bragg position of fcc Co at 44.2°)[35]. Similarly, a similar trend is discernible for the remaining diffraction peaks, including (200) and (220). This phenomenon adheres to Vegard’s law, wherein the position of the XRD diffraction peaks varies systematically with the alloy ratio[36,37]. In summary, during the pyrolysis of these bimetallic CoNi@C-OCPs, Co-Ni alloys are formed within the catalysts Co2Ni8@C and Co8Ni2@C. Furthermore, this signifies that the Co/Ni alloy ratio within the catalyst has been successfully adjusted. As shown in Fig. S4, the metal loading of all catalysts has been analyzed, revealing that the actual molar Co/Ni ratios of the alloy catalysts (Co2Ni8@C and Co8Ni2@C) closely resemble their adding ratios. Moreover, the total metal loading of each catalyst sample exhibits a high degree of similarity. As shown in Fig. 2c and d, the XPS spectra of Ni 2p and Co 2p reveal that all the resulting catalysts with Ni (Ni@C, Co2Ni8@C, and Co8Ni2@C) contain Ni0 and Ni2+ species, while the ones containing Co (Co@C, Co8Ni2@C, and Co2Ni8@C) exhibit Co0 and Co2+ species [38]. The binding energies of all Ni species in the catalyst Co8Ni2@C (the alloy catalyst with the largest Co/Ni ratio) are generally higher than those of the catalysts Ni@C and Co2Ni8@C, with deviations of + 0.5 and + 0.6 eV for Ni0 and Ni2+, respectively. Additionally, the binding energies of all Co species in the alloy catalysts Co8Ni2@C and Co2Ni8@C are generally lower than those in Co@C. In particular, the difference in binding energies also exhibits a regular change with the Co/Ni ratio. As the Co/Ni ratio decreases (from 8: 2 to 2: 8), the difference in binding energies changes from−0.87 to−2.27 eV for Co0 species, and from 0 to−0.8 eV for Co2+ species. In the Co-Ni alloys, the binding energies of Co species undergo a positive shift, whereas those of Ni species experience a negative shift. This shift indicates the presence of electronic interaction between Co and Ni, with Co enhancing the electron cloud density around Ni. This interaction is further modulated by the Co/Ni ratio and may serve as the basis for the unique synergistic effects in Co-Ni alloys[39]. The metallic state of the catalysts was confirmed by X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) at the Ni K-edge and the Co K-edge. It can be seen from the Ni K-edge XANES spectrum (Fig. 3 a) compared with the references of Ni foil and NiO that the Ni element in Ni@C, Co2Ni8@C and Co8Ni2@C is basically in metallic state (Ni0). Similarly, the metallic state (Co0) of Co element in the samples (Co@C, Co2Ni8@C and Co8Ni2@C) is also proved in the Co K-edge XANES spectrum (Fig. 3b)[40]. The coordination environment of the Ni and Co is evaluated by Fourier transformation (FT) using k3-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra of Co K-edge and Ni K-edge. Based on the well-matched EXAFS fitting results of catalysts (Co@C, Co8Ni2@C, Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C), as shown in Fig. 3c, d and Table S1, the main peaks at around 2.18 Å (both Ni-K edge and Co-K edge) in R-space, which are assigned to Co-Co, Ni-Ni and Ni/Co-Co/Ni coordination. And, the calculated coordination numbers for the neighboring Ni-Ni shells in Ni@C and Co-Co shells in Co@C are 8.9 ± 1.1 and 11.5 ± 0.9, respectively. These values closely resemble the coordination numbers reference for Ni foil (12) and Co foil (12). However, in Co2Ni8@C, the coordination numbers of the neighboring Ni-Ni/Co and Co-Co/Ni shells are 4 and 7.1 ± 0.3, respectively. While for Co8Ni2@C, the corresponding coordination numbers of the shells are 6 (Ni-Ni/Co) and 8 (Co-Co/Ni), both of which are significantly lower than the value of 12. This finding suggests that in the catalysts Ni@C and Co@C, the metal Ni and metal Co exist predominantly in the form of monometallic nanoparticles (NPs). Conversely, in the Co2Ni8@C and Co8Ni2@C, the metals are present in the form of Co-Ni alloy NPs[41–43]. The fitting curves of Ni and Co for all catalysts at K-space (Fig. 3e and f) and R-space (Fig. S7 a and b) are exhibited. The integration of wavelet data and R-space fitting information offers a comprehensive insight into the atom coordination scenarios. The diverse colors in wavelet images effectively signify the peak heights, thereby allowing us not only to distinguish the distance between coordinating atoms (bond length), but also the precise type of coordinated atoms. The wavelet results (Fig. 3g) indicate that Ni@C and Co@C only contain the metal–metal coordination environments of Ni-Ni and Co-Co, respectively. Conversely, Co2Ni8@C and Co8Ni2@C exclusively possess the metal coordination environment of Co-Ni or Ni-Co. Combining the results of XRD, XPS, and AAS (Fig. S4), it is reasonably concluded that the Co-Ni alloy NPs are successfully synthesized in Co2Ni8@C and Co8Ni2@C, and the Co/Ni metal ratio is effectively tuned. In contrast, the metals in Ni@C and Co@C consist of respective single-metal NPs. The microstructure and morphology of all catalysts were observed through HRTEM images (Fig. 4 a-d). The metallic Ni NPs in Ni@C and the Co-Ni alloy NPs in Co2Ni8@C are uniformly dispersed on the entire carbon substrate. They also exhibit a typical core–shell nanostructure, comprising inner metal cores and outer graphite carbon shells. In Ni@C, the lattice spacing of 0.209 nm is attributed to the (111) plane of the metallic Ni, and it is also enveloped by 1–3 layers of graphite carbon shells[44]. Similarly, in Co2Ni8@C, the d-spacing of 0.216 nm is indexed to the (111) plane of the metallic Co-Ni alloy, and it also has 1–3 layers of outer graphite carbon layers[45]. Additionally, approximately 60 particles of each catalyst, Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C, were counted separately (as shown in Fig. S5), revealing that they had similar carbon layer numbers (1–3) and metal core particle sizes (8–13 nm). This can be attributed to the fact that they share the same OCPs precursor preparation and pyrolysis conditions. It is worth noting that there is no obvious graphite carbon layer structure at the periphery of the metal NPs in Co8Ni2@C, and Co@C. The lattice spacing of 0.210 nm and 0.203 nm are observed, classified as the (111) crystal plane of the metallic Co-Ni alloy in Co8Ni2@C, and the (111) crystal plane of metallic Co in Co@C[46]. To further clear the differences in the properties of the carbon materials in the catalyst, Raman spectra were performed on all samples (Fig. 5 c). And, to gain more details, we performed peak fitting of the Raman spectra of Ni@C, Co2Ni8@C, Co8Ni2@C, and Co@C, which were decomposed into 4 Gaussian bands. The IG/ID1 ratios of Ni@C, Co2Ni8@C, Co8Ni2@C, and Co@C catalysts correspond to 1.12, 1.04, 0.87, and 0.71, respectively. The distinct G (∼1580 cm−1) and D1 (∼1340 cm−1) bands in their Raman spectra correspond to perfect graphene without defects and the in-plane imperfections in graphite[47]. Hence, this indicates that the degree of graphitization of the carbon material in the catalyst decreases as the Co/Ni ratio increases. In addition, from the left side of Fig. 5c, it can be seen that with the increase in nickel content, the content of the G band also increases, ranging from 16 % to 18 % to 25 % to 29 %. Meanwhile, the defect content, including the D4 (∼1130 cm−1), D1, and D3 (∼1490 cm−1) bands gradually decreases[48]. This further proves that the higher the Ni content in the catalyst, the stronger the graphitization characteristics of its carbon base. And, it is also consistent with the observation in HRTEM, where outer graphitic carbon layers can be observed in catalysts with high Ni content. Furthermore, additional details can be derived from further analysis of TG and XRD. In the TGA analysis, as depicted in the supplementary figure in Fig. 2a, compared to Co8Ni2@C-OCPs and Co@C-OCPs, which have a high Co content, Ni@C-OCPs and Co2Ni8@C-OCPs exhibit a narrower temperature range during the third weight loss interval, enabling the completion of the third stage of weight loss at a lower temperature. This indicates that Ni possesses a higher reactivity compared to Co. Specifically, Ni can undergo redox reactions at lower temperatures, resulting in the formation of metallic Ni and subsequent catalytic graphitization reactions on the metal surface. Moreover, in the Fig. 2b, the characteristic diffraction peak (26.4°) of Graphitic (002) appears in catalysts Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C, which contain higher nickel content. However, the characteristic diffraction peak (47.5°) of Crystalline Carbon (101) appears in catalysts Co@C and Co8Ni2@C. This follows from the fact that Ni exhibits better catalytic graphitization activity than Co, as crystalline carbon serves as a transition state between amorphous carbon and graphitic carbon[49,50]. In addition, a series of experiments has been designed to further explore the nanostructure of the catalyst. All catalysts were being pickled for 5 h, and the concentration of metal ions (Co and Ni) in the pickling solution was being detected. As shown in Fig. 5a, Co@C lost approximately 95.2 % of Co, Co8Ni2@C lost 91.02 % of Ni and 92.86 % of Co. However, for Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C, there is almost no metal loss occurring, including Co and Ni. In summary, after pickling, catalysts Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C maintain their initial metal loading, whereas catalysts Co@C and Co8Ni2@C exhibit an opposite trend. Moreover, as shown in Fig. S6, the hydrogenation of all catalysts was being tested under different conditions. After acid pickling of the catalyst, and the presence of sulfur-containing toxins in the reaction medium, respectively, there is no significant loss of activity observed for Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C, and both maintain a certain degree of activity. On the contrary, both Co8Ni2@C and Co@C lost most of their original catalytic activities. These all indicate that catalysts with high nickel content (Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C) exhibit an outer graphitic carbon layer that grows through catalytic graphitization. This outer layer acts as a barrier, preventing the medium from directly contacting the metal core. As a result, the metal core is effectively protected from damage, especially under harsh conditions[16,51]. It greatly improves the stability of the catalysts. In addition, we had performed H2-TPR tests on all catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5b, the H2-TPR curve of Co8Ni2@C and Co@C showed a peak at∼300 ℃ assigned to the reduction of metal oxide. While no metal oxides are detected in these two samples on the XRD patterns, this absence is likely attributed to the metal oxide content falling below the detection limit of the XRD spectrometer used[52]. In contrast, Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C do not consume hydrogen gas, indicating that their outer carbon layer has an insulating effect on small molecules like H2. Another possibility is that they do not have reducible metal oxides, thereby illustrating the insulating effect of the outer carbon layer on gas molecules (O2). These findings provide sufficient evidence that Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C are special encapsulated catalysts, with transition metals (TMs) completely encapsulated by the graphite carbon layer. Many studies have shown that this type of catalyst has unique characteristics. It is observed that the electrons of TMs can penetrate through the outer graphitic carbon layer, promoting catalytic reactions on the external graphite carbon surface. Simultaneously, the graphite carbon layer serves as a protective barrier for TMs [17,53,54]. 3.3 Catalytic performance To evaluate the catalytic performance of the catalyst samples in the hydrogenation of nitroarene to aniline, the reduction of p-CNB was first chosen as the model reaction. As shown in Fig. 6 a, under the same reaction conditions, 100 % conversion is achieved, requiring only 50 min for Co2Ni8@C and 70 min for Ni@C. However, longer reaction times are required for Co8Ni2@C and Co@C (90 and 100 min, respectively). Notably, Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C exhibit faster reaction rates, with none of the catalyst samples showing significant changes in reaction rate over prolonged reaction times or decreasing substrate concentrations. And, compared to the commercial catalyst Raney-Ni, the catalyst prepared in this study exhibited a higher level of selectivity (Table S2). It is worth noting that the level of catalytic activity appears to be distinguished by the presence of an outer graphite carbon layer in the structure. Catalysts with the outer graphitic carbon layer (Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C) exhibit higher catalytic activity. Catalysts lacking the outer graphitic carbon layer in the structure (Co8Ni2@C and Co@C) exhibit lower catalytic activity. In addition, reusability tests were conducted on all catalyst samples under identical reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 6b, core–shell structured catalysts (Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C) maintained their initial catalytic activity after ten cycles, whereas exposed metal catalysts (Co8Ni2@C and Co@C) exhibited significant performance decline after 3–4 cycles. This stability difference is likely attributed to the effective protection of active metal sites by carbon encapsulation, corroborating previous findings from acid leaching and sulfur poisoning experiments. However, in carbon layer encapsulation structures, high stability is often achieved at the expense of the reactivity of the metal nanoparticles[53,55]. To better understand the reasons for the higher activity of Co2Ni8@C, an analysis was conducted on several factors, including the Co/Ni ratio in the catalyst, catalytic activity, and the degree of graphitization of the carbon support. As the ratio of Co/Ni decreases, the graphitization degree of the carbon support in the catalyst increases, benefiting from Ni's higher catalytic graphitization capability. Moreover, the special structure of graphite carbon encapsulating metal is observed in the catalysts with high nickel content (Ni@C and Co2Ni8@C). Co8Ni2@C and Co@C represent the loading of metal NPs in less graphitized transcrystalline or amorphous carbon carriers. These observations are confirmed in the preceding text. The differences in catalyst structure can be reflected by the degree of graphitization of the carbon base. As the graphitization degree of the carbon support increases, the catalyst should exhibit higher catalytic activity. The high graphitization degree of the carbon support facilitates electronic interaction between the metal and support, leading to improved catalytic performance, as confirmed by numerous studies[56,57]. This also explains why Co8Ni2@C and Co@C, despite having exposed metal sites, display low catalytic activity. However, Ni@C and Co2Ni8@C do not adhere to this regular pattern in our study. Compared to Co2Ni8@C, the carbon support in Ni@C exhibits a higher graphitization degree but corresponds to lower catalytic activity. Further, a comparative analysis of catalytic activity was performed via kinetic experiments between the Ni@C and Co2Ni8@C. Prior to this, under the conditions of 100 °C and 1.0 MPa hydrogen pressure, we evaluated the conversion rates of the target catalyst (Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C) at different agitation speeds (specifically at 10, 30, and 50 min into the reaction). As shown in Fig. S8a and b, when the agitation speed exceeds 1200 rpm, the reaction rate will not be influenced by it. Therefore, all reactions will be carried out at an agitation speed of 1200 rpm. To verify the elimination of external diffusion limitations, we established the correlation between catalyst loading and reaction rate under the condition of the entire liquid phase having the same volume. The catalyst loading was varied from 0.286 to 0.857 mg/mL based on the total liquid phase volume, as depicted in Fig. S8c and d. Additionally, the initial rates of reactions were plotted against catalyst loading (Fig. 7 a), demonstrating a direct proportionality between rates and catalyst loading throughout the liquid phase volume. This further confirms that under these conditions, the reaction is no longer limited by external diffusion. Further removal of intra-particle mass transfer resistance in the catalyst particles can be demonstrated using the Wietz-Prater modulus (Cwp). This modulus can be calculated using the observed rate (robs), effective diffusivity of the limiting reactant (Deff), particle size of the catalyst (Rp), and reactant concentration at the external surface of the particle (Cs)[58,59]. C wp = r obs × R P 2 C s × D eff Here, the upper limit size of Rp is 0.07 mm, and Deff is on the order of magnitude of 10-6 m2/s. In this study, for all the experimental conditions the Cwp values are less than 1.5 × 10-3 based on the catalyst particle size of 150 mesh. When Cwp is much less than 1, it indicates that the reaction is intrinsically kinetically controlled. In conclusion, with a stirring speed of 1200 rpm and catalyst powder with a particle size of 150 mesh, the reaction is no longer influenced by internal and external diffusion but is controlled by intrinsic kinetics. Therefore, all subsequent kinetic experiments will be conducted under these reaction conditions. Moreover, Fig. S9 revealed the high sensitivity of the target catalyst to reaction temperature, indicating that for these catalysts, the hydrogenation reaction is predominantly controlled by surface reactions[60]. Given the fixed amount of catalyst in the experiment and the significantly higher hydrogen concentration compared to the substrate p-CNB, the hydrogen concentration remained relatively constant throughout the reaction process. Consequently, only the reaction order of the substrate p-CNB was determined[61]. Under the predetermined experimental conditions, four different initial concentrations of p-CNB were set. To minimize the impact of product and intermediate concentration on the forward hydrogenation rate of p-CNB, the conversion rate of the reaction was maintained less than 10 % to obtain data points. Subsequently, a relationship curve between ln CA and ln r0 was derived through fitting the data points. Additional specific data can be found in Table S3. Here, CA represents the concentration of p-CNB after the reaction, r0 represents the instantaneous reaction rate during the hydrogenation of p-CNB, but under the assumption of maintaining the conversion rate low, it can be simplified to an average reaction rate to streamline calculations. As shown in Fig. 7c, the reaction order of the substrate p-CNB on Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C are∼0.8. And, compared with Ni@C, Co2Ni8@C demonstrates a faster intrinsic reaction rate. Based on the Arrhenius Equation, Co2Ni8@C (53.40 KJ/mol) exhibits a lower apparent activation energy than Ni@C (64.25 KJ/mol) within the temperature range of 323.15–383.15 K (Fig. 7d)[62]. More specific data can be found in Table S4. These results indicate that Co2Ni8@C exhibits superior catalytic activity under identical conditions, aligning with previous observations. Furthermore, to eliminate differences in catalyst activity due to factors such as reaction time, metal content, and metal dispersion, and to focus more on inherent differences in reactivity at the catalytic active sites themselves, we normalized the activity data of the catalyst samples for further comparison. This normalized value, was calculated as the number of moles of p-CNB reacted per unit time divided by the total moles of metal in the catalyst[63]. The value of Co2Ni8@C (107.73 h−1) is nearly twice that of Ni@C (54.88h−1). However, a key factor in the difference between the activity of catalysts Ni@C and Co2Ni8@C has been ignored. The original graphitic carbon alone in the reaction is inherently inert due to its low density of states (DOS) near the Fermi level. But, in the encapsulated catalysts, the electronic interaction and charge redistribution between the metal and the carbon layer leads to an increase in the electronic DOS of graphitic carbon at the Fermi level. This phenomenon ultimately enhances the reaction activity[16,51]. Therefore, the contribution of the encapsulated metal core to the catalytic performance, as the provider of electrons, is critical. After the low-temperature NH4Cl treatment[64], the encapsulated metal nanoparticles in the catalysts Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C were removed, leaving only their outer carbon shells, designated as Co2Ni8@C-shell and Ni@C-shell, respectively. As shown in the Fig. 7a, the samples lost their catalytic activity after the removal of the metal nanoparticles. This outcome clearly indicates that the catalytic activity of Co2Ni8@C and Ni@C relies entirely on the metal nanoparticles encapsulated by the carbon shells, and the difference in catalytic activity between the two directly stems from the distinct compositions of these metal nanoparticles. Alloying and subsequent treatments can adjust the electron-donating ability of the metal core and correspondingly alter its d-band structure, a change that depends on the degree of d-band overlap between the two metals composing the alloy[23]. Therefore, the unique Co-Ni alloy metal core in Co2Ni8@C is likely to be one of the key factors contributing to its outstanding catalytic performance. Moreover, it exhibits excellent performance when dealing with nitrobenzenes with various substituents. (See Scheme 1 ). 3.4 DFT simulations Therefore, DFT simulation was utilized to verify the influence of the metal core within the encapsulated structure. To eliminate external factors such as catalyst particle size and the number of outer carbon layers and simplify the catalyst model for clarity, we designed a simplified carbon-covered metal model. This model focuses only on the interface between the metal core and the immediately adjacent carbon shell, accurately capturing the unique characteristic of encapsulated catalysts where the external carbon layer serves as the reaction site and the reactants do not directly interact with the metal. Specifically, for Ni@C, the model consists of 72 carbon atoms covering 64 nickel atoms (C72Ni64). Similarly, for Co2Ni8@C, the model consists of 72 carbon atoms covering a Co-Ni alloy with 54 nickel atoms and 10 cobalt atoms (C72Ni54Co10), with a metal ratio similar to the Co2Ni8@C sample in the experiments. Fig. 8 a shows the DOS and the corresponding d-band center values for the catalysts. Notably, the d-band center of the C72Ni54Co10 (−1.55 eV) is significantly higher than that of C72Ni64 (−1.78 eV), and its position is closer to the Fermi level (Ef = 0). This indicates the profound influence of Co-Ni metal core alloying. The alloying seemingly overcomes the shielding effect imposed by the carbon layer on the d-orbitals of the metal cores, potentially resulting in more optimized adsorption and desorption behaviors of reactants/products on the catalyst surface[65,66]. Further DFT simulations revealed the adsorption of reactants (p-CNB and H2) by carbon layers underlying different metal cores. As shown in Fig. 8b, the surface adsorption energy (Eads) of p-CNB and H2 on the C72Ni54Co10 are−0.923 eV and−0.534 eV, respectively, in comparison with those of C72Ni64 (−0.228 eV and−0.103 eV), demonstrating that C72Ni54Co10 has a stronger adsorption capability for the reactants, including p-CNB and H2, which may be conducive to the progress of the reaction. In addition, the stronger adsorption of H2 on the alloy catalyst was further verified from an experimental perspective by H2-TPD. As shown in Fig. 8c, a low temperature peak at 92 °C is observed in the TPD profiles, which can be attributed to the adsorption of molecular H2 on the surface of Ni@C and Co2Ni8@C[67]. The peaks at 519 °C for Co2Ni8@C and 509 °C for Ni@C are attributed to the adsorption of dissociative hydrogen on the graphite carbon layer within the respective catalyst[68]. Because of the electron supply from the metal core, the graphite carbon layer no longer exhibits reaction inertness and acquires a certain degree of reactivity. The Co2Ni8@C exhibits a higher desorption temperature, indicating that it has stronger chemical adsorption of H2. This finding is consistent with the ordering of the relative positions between the d-band center and the Fermi level in the catalyst. Specifically, the closer the d-band center of the catalyst is to the Fermi level, the stronger its interaction with surface substances such as hydrogen and p-CNB becomes. And, further reaction path simulations for the hydrogenation of p-CNB to p-CAN were conducted on different catalyst surfaces. Drawing from previous research, we employed the monomolecular reaction pathway of the Haber reaction mechanism (Fig. S10) as our guiding framework[1,17,22,69]. First, p-CNB is hydrogenated and dehydrated to obtain p-chloronitrosobenzene (p-NSB) intermediate, and then p-NSB is reduced by H2 to obtain intermediate p-chlorophenylhydroxylamine (p-PHA), and finally p-PHA is further hydrogenated and dehydrated to obtain final product p-CAN[33,70]. Based on this, as shown in Fig. 9 , on the surface of C72Ni54Co10, which exhibits stronger adsorption strength towards the substrates (p-CNB and H2), the hydrogenation reaction at each step has the lowest reaction energy. This indicates that the hydrogenation conversion of p-CNB to p-CAN on C72Ni54Co10 surface has a more favorable reaction kinetic pathway compared to C72Ni64. This corresponds to the experimental result that Co2Ni8@C has the strongest catalytic hydrogenation activity. In summary, compared to C72Ni64, C72Ni54Co10 exhibits stronger adsorption of the substrates (p-CNB and H2) and has a more optimized hydrogenation reaction path on the catalyst surface. On this basis, we compared the electronic structure differences caused by the different types of encapsulated metal cores. As shown in Fig. 10 a, the charge density redistributions of two systems: C72Ni54Co10 and C72Ni64 were calculated using DFT simulations. Compared with pure Ni, the introduction of Co results in the formation of a Co-Ni alloy, which changes the charge density of the carbon layer and metal system, leading to an increased accumulation of charges on the carbon layer. And, it promotes the electronic interaction between the metal and carbon layers[71]. Moreover, the Electron Localization Functions (ELFs) were used to investigate the electron interaction between the carbon layer and metal[72,73]. As shown in Fig. 10b, the carbon layer is separated from the metal by a blue region (representing an ELFs value of approximately 0), which signifies the existence of regions with minimal electron density between them. The carbon layer atoms are encircled by orange circles, signifying the accumulation of electrons predominantly outside the C atoms. This observation aligns with the well-established characteristics of ionic bonds and implies that the metal can donate electrons to the carbon layer[74–76]. Additionally, the formal charge transfer within the model was quantitatively evaluated using Bader charge analysis. As shown in Table 1 , each carbon atom in C72Ni54Co10 receives an average of 0.022 electrons provided by metal atoms, including Ni and Co, whereas in C72Ni64, only 0.011 electrons are acquired. This finding is also consistent with the previous conclusion of XPS. Thus, it is concluded that the alloying of Co-Ni can overcome the limitations imposed by carbon layers and pump more original metal electrons to the carbon layer, which serve as the reactivity source of the encapsulated catalyst. 4 Conclusions In summary, we had successfully synthesized a series of alloy catalysts with a tunable Co/Ni ratio through the simple pyrolysis of OCP precursors. And, due to the high catalytic graphitization capability of Ni, the graphitization characteristics of the carbon support within the catalyst are proportional to the Ni content. Thus, catalysts Ni@C and Co2Ni8@C with high Ni content, also exhibit a special structure where the graphite carbon layer encapsulates the metal core. Notably, Co2Ni8@C demonstrates superior catalytic hydrogenation activity. Even in the presence of sulfur poisoning and after acid washing, the catalyst retains a certain level of its original activity. Furthermore, Co2Ni8@C maintains its catalytic performance even after 10 reaction cycles and demonstrates strong adaptability towards the hydrogenation of nitroaromatic compounds. DFT simulations had shed light on the source of the catalytic activity of Co2Ni8@C. The Co-Ni alloy metal core facilitates the transfer of more electrons to the outer carbon layer, enhancing the reactivity of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Encapsulated catalysts have become a new strategy for catalysis in harsh reaction environments due to their unique structural and functional reorganization properties, and they have been widely applied in fields such as electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and thermocatalysis. In strategies involving encapsulated catalysts, the optimization of electronic properties on the carbon layer surface to enhance reactivity while maintaining adequate encapsulation poses a challenge due to the trade-off between stability, poison resistance, and acid resistance against the performance of metal nanoparticles. Herein, an alloying strategy for Co-Ni bimetal was proposed, which achieves a delicate balance between catalyst activity and stability. Ni plays a pivotal role in promoting the formation of graphitized carbon and the construction of an effective encapsulation structure, thereby ensuring the stability of the catalyst. Co incorporation and alloying with Ni modulates the electronic state and D-band structure within the metallic core, effectively breaking the electronic cloud segregation barrier imposed by the carbon shell. This modulation notably enhances the efficiency of reactions. For the hydrogenation of p-CNB to p-CAN, Co2Ni8@C exhibits an extremely low apparent activation energy (53.40 KJ/mol), as well as > 99 % conversion and selectivity.

coredata.dc:title: Enhancing electron penetration through carbon shell of encapsulated catalysts by Co alloying for aromatic nitrobenzene hydrogenation
